results.title: The Rutles
results.creator_credit: Rutles, Craig Kellem, Gary Weis and Eric Idle
results.brief_description: The Rutles is a mockumentary, a parody of The Beatles and Beatlemania written and co-directed by Eric Idle, of Monty Python fame. The Rutles are Dirk, Barry, Stig and Nasty. Made for television, “The Rutles” charts the rise of the band of the same name as they progress from English obscurity to world phenomena. Using mockumentary footage and interviews, “The Rutles” documents the pre-fab four’s journey right through to their messy break up and post-Rutle lives. Idle plays a series of characters including Rutle Dirk and a hapless BBC type interviewer who narrates the film. “The Rutles” mocks the BBC, documentary filmmakers, and The Beatles’ films and music. Features excerpts from The Rutles films - Yellow Submarine Sandwich, Tragical History Tour, OUCH!, and A Hard Day’s Rut. Songs include Please rut me, All you need is cash and Twist and rut. “The Rutles” also features George Harrison, John Belushi, Dan Ackroyd, Bianca Jagger, Ron Wood, Mick Jagger, Paul Simon and Bill Murray. “The Rutles” is a sharp and witty send up of any number of documentaries made about The Beatles.

results.title: The Ruthless one
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and Douglas Gordon
results.brief_description: The life cycle of the desert locust is traced; copulation, female laying eggs, hatching, subsequent growth and casting of skin and formation of migratory swarms.

results.title: The Rutherford atom
results.creator_credit: Kevin Smith, Quentin Brown, Physical Sciences Study Committee and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
A cloud chamber and gold foil in a simple alpha-particle scattering experiment illustrates the historic Rutherford experiment which led to the nuclear model of the atom. Behaviour of alpha particles clarified by use of large scale models illustrating the nuclear atom and Coulomb scattering.

results.title: The Russians
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield, John Abbott and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Russians”.
A three part series examining life in the Soviet Union. This episode studies Kierov, Kuban, Belarussia and Siberia. Narrated by Nick Tate, cinematography by Dean Semler.

results.title: The Russian consumer
results.creator_credit: Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Discusses the Russian consumer and the prices of the goods and housing availability. After decades of development at the expense of the consumer the Soviet economy now provides a higher standard of living, however, improvements remain out of reach of most of the peasants.

results.title: The Running broad jump
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Track and Field Instruction”.
The technique of long jumping is shown in normal and slow motion speeds. Provides an analysis of the movements and the physical forces that are significant features of this event; shows single “hitch kick” action and outlines training programs and practices to aid the beginner.

results.title: The Runner
results.creator_credit: Alireza Zarrin, Inst for the Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults and Amir Naderi
results.brief_description: Buoyed by an extraordinary performance from Majid Nirumand, “Runner” is an evocative, memorable slice of life drama about an orphaned street kid who lives alone on a beached boat on the edge of the Persian Gulf and who, as the film progresses, attempts a variety of jobs to survive. The first post-revolution Iranian film to be released internationally, Naderi’s film is a beautifully photographed, deceptively simple film which is decidedly sophisticated in the ways it changes mood. Raw in parts, upbeat in others, Runner brilliantly uses striking images and sound to take you right into Amiro’s world. Winner of the International Critics Prize at the Melbourne Film Festival.

results.title: The Runaways
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Charles Dickens”.
A tale of childhood romance about the 9-year-old Harry Walmers and his fiance, both guests at the Holly Tree Inn, who elope with the help fo the hostess, Mrs Piff, Boots and the other servants. Introductor narration filmed in Dickens’ home.
